Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story: I was sitting on the couch, holding my husband’s trembling hand as he tried to steady his breathing. He’d barely slept in days, and I knew he needed me—my words, my touch, my presence. I stroked his arm, whispering that I was here, that we’d get through this together. My phone buzzed on the coffee table. I glanced at the screen: it was my best friend, Sarah. I hesitated, but answered quietly. Her voice was shaky, on the verge of tears. “Can you talk? I just had a huge fight with Mark. I really need you right now.” I looked at my husband, his eyes pleading for me not to leave his side, even for a moment. My heart twisted. Sarah had always been there for me, and I knew she was counting on me to listen, to help her sort through her pain. But my husband’s grip tightened, silently begging me to stay. I felt torn in two, the weight of both their needs pressing down on me, unsure how to be the support they each so desperately needed at the same time.
